Career growth: plenty of internal transfer options. I mean...it's Alibaba, there's no corner in the business world left untouched by it yet (we're talking about mainland China only).
cons: Toxic culture. Almost no wlb (although it's getting better since 2021). Promotion and salary increase all depend on your team leader (normally the P9). Too big to fail but also too big to see your own way out.

review_title: A depressing but not unbearable place to work
pros: Good office facilities, fair compensation, and some kind individuals.
cons:
If you were charmed by the Jack Ma narrative and think that Alibaba is different from most other Chinese conglomerates, think again -- he's gone and whoever took his place is asleep at the wheel, at least when it comes to this team. When you look past the facade of a fancy office and other surface-level / material perks, this is a deeply soulless and unsatisfying place to work. 

Being outside of the Hangzhou HQ, you will almost certainly have no real power to change anything. I'm pretty sure upper leadership would agree to this point behind closed doors, as they are obviously kowtowing to HQ as they spend their days in endless meetings, pretending to have any actual clout in the greater organization. It must kill them inside, but they get paid enough to be okay with indefinitely being a cog. 

Besides the lack of heed paid to "local" hires, I have never seen a company with such a near-criminal disregard for its customers despite claiming to be "customer first." I witnessed countless instances of negligence and fraud without there ultimately being any accountability for those culpable. Escalation of such issues was clearly unwelcome, as that would involve a disproportionate amount of work up the chain of command to address what would never have occurred were there a functional resolution process to begin with. 

This is a bureaucratic nightmare of a corporate culture, complete with top-down "command and control" and endless layers of nebulous middle management who care little for their reports and are desperate to game their KPIs for promotion. If it's not attached to an already decided-upon KPI, it may as well not exist, as evinced by a customer experience that is qualitatively awful, because leadership is happy as long as the revenue numbers keep going up. This myopic approach fails to consider how much growth potential is still goes wasted, but this is a place that is all about blind cheerleading and shuns meaningful critique or dissent. All tropes of hypocrisy with regard to a company's stated values are at play here.

One of my most trenchant and instructive memories during my time at Alibaba was at the goodbye drinks for a bright, talented colleague who had worked there for years. Once most people had filtered out, she began to cry, because no matter how hard they worked, and after all those years of their life, almost nothing they did ended up making a difference to the product or company. 

The main takeaway I had working here is that you can take away a solid paycheck, but you have to be okay with having almost no real impact. If you want to go the established-company route, I would advise advise that you save yourself some time and frustration you work to get into a Western company.

review_title: Don't waste your valuable time to work at Alibaba.

cons:
1. Alibaba don't treat their employees right. You will have a lot of overtime without paid or compensation day, including working at nights, weekends, holidays and vacation days.
2. It is impossible to have a well balance of life if you work at Alibaba. Every time is changing. Everything seems urgent and important. At the end, you will sacrify all your personal time and relationships to the company. I saw a lot of real  examples.
3. Your career path is really hard to grow at Alibaba. Alibaba believes that everyone can do anyone's job. They can allocate you to any position you might not be capable of. 4. Most of the Alibaba employees are inexperienced fresh graduated student. It is very difficult to work with and expect  them to have some standard professional manner.

review_title: You must be a fighter to survive!
job_title: User Experience Designer in Hangzhou, Zhejiang
pros:
✦ Great people. I mean it. Not taking into account the work environment, the people at Alibaba.com are smart, talented, curious, and great at building relationships. 

✦  Alibaba's culture is ingrained into the very fabric of what everyone does here. So make yourself aware of the organization culture before you accept the offer. If the culture is not something you would like, then it would be a loss for you and the company. 

✦ Benefits are good, if not excellent!

✦  You get to learn from the industry experts. People have been here for over 10 years and are subject matter experts in their respective fields. So, leave no stone unturned to learn from them!
cons:
- Work-life balance is stretched to the max here.

- The business direction can change frequently, so sometimes your projects might not get live.

- Performance is everything. You must fight for everything. The strongest survive, as it is a harsh environment.

- The organization structure is not the same as other western/US based companies. There are multiple hierarchies so you need to be aware of who to connect with to get things done. 

- And of course, needless to say, the language barrier is a major concern. It is a Chinese company and people are proud of it. But that makes everyday communications with Business and other teams a huge challenge for any foreigner who doesn't speak Mandarin.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Mateo, CA
pros: There are Some good people to work with.
cons:
It's not a startups culture, it is disorganized and has no strategies.  The decision making is top down, HQ doesn't know the US market but involved deeply for everything. 
Don't try to suggest any new ideas, you will get punished and your manager will exclude you from the works.
Very Chinese type company in a negative way doing business. Doesn't care about employee benefit, salary is lower than the market but you are required to travel more than 30% and non stop working at night, the kitchen area is dirty most of the time,  No free company parking lots, you will need to pay for parking out of your pocket $125 per month. If you don't know Chinese you will have hard time to use the internal system.

review_title: Chaotic, no meritocracy, Chinese colleagues get preferential treatment, internal politics.
pros:
High business growth.
Innovation leader in China. 
Ambitious growth strategy and growth targets.
Equity linked compensation. 
Great place to learn to speak Mandarin.
cons:
Strategy changes few times per year resulting in reorganisations and it impacts job security, team morale and internal growth opportunities. 
Key decision makers are in China, international offices execute with little input. 
Chinese colleagues have better chance at promotion especially at more senior positions.
Chinese colleagues cluster and don't mingle with international colleagues.
Terrible work life balance, meetings are regularly scheduled on Beijing time leading to many midnight calls and emailing.
Meetings quickly switch to Chinese if one attendee doesn't speak well English to the detriment of international colleagues. 
Senior meetings are completely in Chinese. 
Chaotic "startup" environment.
Cult like culture of glorifying the founders, emphasis on personal sacrifice for benefit of the team, company and country.
Questionable transferable skills and knowledge.

pros:
The Alibaba Group has a lot of subsidiaries such as Alibaba(focus on B2B trading), Taobao(focus on C2C trading), Tmall(focus on B2C trading), Cainiao(focus on logistics business), Ali Cloud(cloud computing firm), Ali OS(developed OS used in phones and tv sets), etc. And it also bought a few companies in the past several years, like Gaode(online map and navigation system), UC(1st mobile browser in China), Youku(Youtube copy, 1st rank in China), etc.
As an engineer in the huge company, you can do whatever you want from the kernel level business(Ali OS) to Web development. It's the possibilities for an engineer to know lots of different business.
cons: Many of the products might be driven by business development. It's hard to say this is pros or cons. For any product, engineer development is only one part, the other parts include marketing, business, etc. These people should work together to achieve success.
